study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms underlying changes in eating behavior, food intake, and body weight after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery induces neurological and physiological changes affecting hypothalamic signaling, gut hormones, bile acids, and gut microbiota, which collectively influence eating behavior. Additive or synergistic effects of conditioned and unconditioned factors likely account for the changes observed post-surgery.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms of weight loss and metabolic improvements following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and sleeve gastrectomy (SG), highlighting similarities and differences between the two procedures.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery, particularly RYGB and SG, results in marked sustained weight loss, improved obesity-associated comorbidities, and reduced mortality. However, post-operative outcomes vary, with some patients experiencing poor long-term weight loss and minimal health benefits. The study highlights the role of gut hormones, bile acids, and gut microbiota in these outcomes.
population_specificity: People with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the current state of bariatric surgery in Canada, including procedure volume, types, outcomes, complications, and barriers to access.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery in Canada leads to sustained weight loss and improved comorbidities, with complication rates similar to those in the literature, but access remains limited due to various barriers. Approximately 8,583 publicly funded surgeries were performed in 2015/2016, with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy being the most common procedures.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery in Canada (9 of 10 provinces).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the prevalence, predictors, and correlates of psychopathology and its associations with weight loss in adolescents with severe obesity 24 months after weight loss surgery (WLS).
results_summary: At 24 months, approximately one in three adolescents were symptomatic with psychopathology, with maintenance or remission of symptoms more common than new incidence. Preoperative psychopathology and loss of control eating were significant predictors, but symptomatology was not predictive of surgical weight loss outcomes.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity undergoing weight loss surgery (n=139) and nonsurgical comparisons (n=83).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of probiotic supplementation on morbidities related to One Anastomosis Gastric Bypass-Mini Gastric Bypass (OAGB-MGB) surgery.
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation significantly improved inflammatory markers, vitamin D status, and anthropometric measurements compared to placebo, though glycemic and lipid profile improvements were similar in both groups. No significant difference was observed in vitamin B levels.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients referred for OAGB-MGB surgery at a tertiary referral center.
study_duration: 4 weeks prior to surgery to 12 weeks after surgery (total 16 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure readmissions after initial bariatric surgery and identify nonclinical factors associated with these readmissions.
results_summary: The study found a 5.5% readmission rate, with 48% of readmissions being preventable and linked to gastrointestinal issues like nausea and vomiting. Nonpreventable readmissions were associated with major complications, but payor status and distance from the hospital did not significantly affect readmission rates.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing initial Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy at a rural U.S. academic hospital between 2007 and 2015.
study_duration: Retrospective analysis covering surgeries performed from May 1, 2007, to April 30, 2015.

study_goal: To comparatively evaluate the results of mini-gastric bypass/one anastomosis gastric bypass (MGB/OAGB) with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) after 1-year follow-up.
results_summary: The study found that both techniques were effective, with OAGB being easier to perform and requiring less surgical time. Patients achieved significant BMI reductions (27.7 ± 7.85 kg/m² for OAGB vs. 29 ± 4.52 kg/m² for RYGB).
population_specificity: 200 patients (100 OAGB, 100 RYGB) with obesity, aged 39-40 years, BMI ~44-45 kg/m², operated between 2008-2016.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of bariatric surgery on obesity and associated comorbidities using metabolomics, focusing on molecular modulations and potential improvements in treatment methods.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery induces significant metabolic changes, including alterations in amino acids, lipids, carbohydrates, and gut microbiota, supporting its role in metabolic surgery. However, many molecular mechanisms remain unexplained, highlighting the need for further metabolomics research.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on obesity and associated comorbidities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of bariatric surgery on lipoprotein metabolism and its implications for type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery lowers triglycerides, contributing to improved lipoprotein metabolism in individuals with type 2 diabetes. The abstract suggests that weight loss interventions like bariatric surgery may help mitigate dyslipidemia associated with insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes and associated dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent literature on how bariatric surgery affects gut gene expression, particularly in relation to glucose metabolism and nutrient pathways.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery alters intestinal gene expression, impacting glucose metabolism and reducing genes linked to vitamin B12 metabolism, potentially contributing to postoperative deficiency. It is effective for sustained weight loss and comorbidity reduction, with nutritional genomic changes suggesting adaptive gut responses.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if substantial pre-conception weight loss using a VLED improves pregnancy outcomes for both mother and baby compared to standard care.
results_summary: The abstract suggests bariatric surgery reduces maternal risks but may increase infant risks, and the study intends to explore VLED as an alternative for improving pregnancy outcomes. No specific results are provided yet.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-38 years with a BMI of 30-55 kg/m² planning pregnancy.

study_goal: To compare the effects of sleeve gastrectomy with transit bipartition (SG + TB) versus standard medical therapy (SMT) in mildly obese patients with type II diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: SG + TB significantly reduced HbA1c levels and BMI compared to SMT at 24 months, demonstrating superior metabolic and cardiovascular outcomes. SMT showed no significant changes in HbA1c or BMI.
population_specificity: Male adults ≤ 65 years old with T2D and BMI > 28 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if preoperative body fat mass and distribution measured by DXA could predict weight loss and metabolic outcomes after RYGB, and to compare DXA's predictive value with simple anthropometric measures.
results_summary: The study found that all clinical, anthropometric, and DXA measures improved significantly after RYGB. Android/gynoid fat mass ratio and waist-to-hip-ratio predicted improved insulin sensitivity, while body fat percentage and BMI predicted weight loss. DXA and anthropometric measures performed similarly as predictors, with DXA-measured fat percentage slightly outperforming formula estimates.
population_specificity: 215 women scheduled for RYGB at four Swedish hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the signs and symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy (WE) after bariatric surgery, focusing on patient characteristics and treatment adequacy.
results_summary: The study found that WE after bariatric surgery often presents with vomiting, ataxia, altered mental status, and eye movement disorders, with younger age and higher BMI appearing protective against some symptoms. Treatment was frequently insufficient, with low parenteral thiamine levels often ignored.
population_specificity: 118 WE cases post-bariatric surgery, primarily younger patients (median age 33 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in reactivating the hypothalamic-pituitary-testicular (HPT) axis in markedly obese men and compare it to lifestyle measures and testosterone treatment.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be very effective in reactivating the HPT axis in markedly obese men, while lifestyle measures had modest effects. Testosterone treatment showed modest benefits on symptoms of androgen deficiency and body composition but did not significantly reduce body weight.
population_specificity: Markedly obese men with obesity-associated nonclassical hypogonadism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the long-term effects of bariatric and metabolic surgery on patients with T2DM and evaluate potential mechanisms for improved glycemic control.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery improves comorbid conditions like hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and T2DM, with metabolic benefits linked to endocrine changes, bacterial flora rearrangement, bile acids secretion, and adipose tissue effects.
population_specificity: Patients with T2DM and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of a fully trans-oral gastrointestinal bypass implant as an alternative to traditional bariatric surgery for weight loss and diabetes management.
results_summary: The study found that the trans-oral device was successfully implanted in all subjects with no intraoperative adverse events or infections, leading to significant weight loss (44.8% excess body weight, 17.6% total body weight) and diabetes remission in 80% of diabetic subjects at 12 months. Weight loss was greater in subjects with proper cuff placement.
population_specificity: 32 obese subjects with a mean BMI of 42.3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-utility and health outcomes of bariatric surgery compared to non-surgical usual care for patients with morbid obesity in England.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery reduced mean healthcare costs by €2742 (£1944) and gained 0.8 life-years and 4.0 QALYs over a lifetime compared to usual care. It also lowered lifetime risks of obesity-related cardiovascular diseases and diabetes, though delaying surgery by 3 years reduced QALYs by 0.7 and costs by €2058 (£1459).
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity in England.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review FDA-approved and investigational devices and endoscopic bariatric therapies for obesity treatment, focusing on their mechanisms, efficacy, and safety.
results_summary: The study found that devices and endoscopic procedures are emerging as minimally invasive, reversible, and potentially more effective than medications, safer for poor surgical candidates, and possibly less expensive than bariatric surgery. A multidisciplinary approach combining various strategies may lead to additive or synergistic weight loss.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity, particularly poor surgical candidates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current data on the skeletal consequences of bariatric surgery and explore preventive strategies to mitigate bone deterioration post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, while effective for treating morbid obesity, poses risks for metabolic bone disease due to rapid weight loss, dietary restrictions, and reduced nutrient absorption. Malabsorptive procedures carry higher bone health risks than restrictive ones, though both types negatively impact skeletal health.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery, particularly those with morbid obesity and associated comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence for bariatric surgery as a treatment option for severe obesity in adolescents, considering its role within broader obesity management strategies.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery should be considered for adolescents with severe obesity, provided it is performed by skilled surgeons within experienced multidisciplinary teams. It emphasizes the importance of long-term behavior modification and weight maintenance strategies alongside surgical intervention.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of endoscopic stent treatment for fistulas developed after bariatric surgeries, specifically Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and gastric sleeve (GS).
results_summary: The study found that endoscopic stent treatment for fistulas after GS or RYGB can be safe and effective in selected patients, with outcomes including overall success rate of fistula closure, mean number of stents per patient, mean stent dwelling time, and procedure-associated complications.
population_specificity: Patients with fistulas after RYGB or GS who received stent treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether patients with diabetes benefit from bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery demonstrated significant benefits for patients with diabetes, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. It was included among high-quality studies with potential effects on primary care.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of adipocyte size in metabolic health and evaluate interventions, including bariatric surgery, to improve cellular function.
results_summary: The study found that reducing large fat cells through bariatric surgery improves cellular function and metabolic health, while small fat cells may also be dysfunctional and unable to expand.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of adipose tissue biology)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in managing NAFLD, particularly in non-responders with morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study suggests bariatric surgery as a viable option for NAFLD patients with morbid obesity who do not respond to lifestyle modifications, alongside metabolic endoscopy and pharmacological therapy for specific cases.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD and morbid obesity who are non-responders to weight loss measures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare long-term survival rates and diabetes-related end-organ damage between overweight/obese type 2 diabetic patients receiving metabolic surgery versus medical treatment.
results_summary: The study recruited 1016 participants, including 126 who underwent metabolic surgery and 890 who received medical treatment, but no specific outcomes on survival or end-organ damage were reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese type 2 diabetic patients with BMI > 25 kg/m² and diabetes duration > 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the role of bariatric surgery in patients with systolic heart failure (HF) and obesity, focusing on its safety and efficacy.
results_summary: Bariatric surgeries like LSG and RYGB were found to be effective for long-term weight loss, diabetes and hypertension remission, and improvements in cardiovascular outcomes, including reduced HF admissions. Safety data supported their use in patients with systolic dysfunction.
population_specificity: Patients aged <50-60 years with severely depressed systolic function, NYHA II-III symptoms, and obesity who failed non-surgical strategies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if physical training after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) could further improve markers of low-grade inflammation and endothelial function beyond the effects of surgery alone.
results_summary: RYGB significantly improved markers of inflammation (IL-6, CRP) and endothelial function (ICAM-1, t-PA:Ag, vWF), with sustained effects at 24 months post-surgery. Supervised physical training after RYGB did not provide additional improvements in these markers.
population_specificity: Sixty patients approved for RYGB.
effective_dosage: Two weekly sessions of supervised moderate-intensity physical training for 26 weeks.
study_duration: 24 months post-surgery (with physical training intervention at 6 months post-surgery for 26 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the medium-term outcomes and safety of laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass with fundectomy and exploration of the gastric remnant (LRYGBfse) as a treatment for morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found that LRYGBfse was safe and effective, with durable weight loss results at 5-year follow-up. Endoscopic exploration of the gastric remnant was noted as an additional valuable tool.
population_specificity: Patients with BMI > 35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and risks of bariatric surgery, particularly focusing on iron deficiency as a postoperative complication, and to advocate for more nutrition-related research in this patient population.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed greater and sustained improvements in weight loss, obesity-associated complications, all-cause mortality, and quality of life compared to non-surgical treatments, but it also carried a significant risk of iron deficiency postoperatively, with prevalence varying by procedure type. The study highlighted the need for better diagnostic and treatment strategies for iron deficiency in bariatric surgery patients.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specifically Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of GLP-1 in the benefits and side effects of bariatric surgery, focusing on its impact on islet function, appetite, inflammation, and cardiovascular pathophysiology.
results_summary: The study highlights GLP-1's role in controlling meal-related glycemic excursions, inhibiting gastric emptying and food intake, and its potential in optimizing metabolic disease treatments. It also discusses the development of GLP-1R-targeting therapies for diabetes and obesity.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The abstract does not address bariatric surgery; it focuses on Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) and obesity as a risk factor for knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with disabling knee osteoarthritis, particularly those with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine racial and ethnic disparities in obesity prevalence and treatment response, including the role of bariatric surgery in equitable treatment plans.
results_summary: The study found higher obesity prevalence and reduced treatment response to lifestyle, behavior, pharmacotherapy, and surgery in racial and ethnic minorities, highlighting the need for improved access and research.
population_specificity: Racial and ethnic minorities in the USA, including pediatric and adult populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefit/risk ratio of bariatric surgery by identifying predictive factors of mortality and severe postoperative complications.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative evaluation and management of comorbidities can reduce postoperative complications and improve overall patient outcomes, though high-risk patients remain vulnerable. Key risk factors include age, BMI, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery, particularly those with high perioperative risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide updated guidelines and best practices for bariatric surgery, addressing current controversies, techniques, and training.
results_summary: The expert panel addressed expanded indications for metabolic surgery in diabetes treatment, safety and efficacy of new endoluminal procedures, and updated guidelines for patient management and training. The summary highlights the evolving nature of bariatric surgery and the need for systematic approaches to inform best practices.
population_specificity: Obese patients and bariatric surgery practitioners.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide guidance on vitamin D assessment and management, particularly for populations like those with osteoporosis or after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that for certain populations, including post-bariatric surgery patients, monitoring circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels is important, but general screening has not been shown to improve health. A "reasonable" level of 30 ng/mL is recommended for those requiring testing.
population_specificity: Individuals with osteoporosis or those who have undergone bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified for bariatric surgery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of miRNAs in enteroendocrine cells (EECs) and their potential relevance to the metabolic effects of bariatric surgery, particularly in type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that certain miRNAs are highly enriched in EECs and may regulate their differentiation and function, suggesting a potential mechanism for the rapid metabolic benefits of bariatric surgery. Recent findings also indicate that EECs might secrete miRNAs into circulation, opening new therapeutic possibilities.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on cellular and molecular mechanisms in EECs and intestinal stem cells).

study_goal: To develop and validate a new BODY-Q scale to measure the appearance of stretch marks in patients undergoing weight loss or body contouring, incorporating patient perspectives into future treatment studies.
results_summary: The Stretch Marks scale demonstrated high reliability (Cronbach's alpha = 0.97) and construct validity, correlating with the number of body areas with stretch marks and higher pre-surgery BMI. The scale fit the Rasch model well after refinement, with no evidence of bias by gender, age, or language.
population_specificity: 403 weight loss and 331 body contouring patients.

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of lower esophageal sphincter electrical stimulation (LES-ES) in post-laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) patients with GERD refractory to proton pump inhibitors (PPI).
results_summary: LES-ES significantly improved GERD symptoms, reduced esophageal acid exposure, and decreased PPI use in post-LSG patients with refractory GERD, offering a viable alternative to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
population_specificity: Post-LSG patients with GERD not controlled by maximal PPI therapy (17 patients, 65% female, median age 48.6 years, median BMI 31.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of supervised physical training following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery (RYGB) on body weight and cardiovascular risk markers.
results_summary: RYGB significantly reduced body weight and improved cardiovascular risk markers. Supervised physical training further enhanced weight loss (4.2 kg more than controls) and temporarily improved high-density lipoprotein levels, though this effect was not sustained at 24 months.
population_specificity: Sixty participants eligible for RYGB.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery could improve symptoms and reduce healthcare utilization related to plantar fasciitis (PF) in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that 90% of patients achieved resolution of PF symptoms after bariatric surgery, with a significant reduction in the number of treatment modalities used postoperatively. Mean BMI and excess weight loss improved post-surgery, suggesting a potential association between weight reduction and PF symptom relief.
population_specificity: Obese patients (mean preintervention BMI 45 ± 7.7) with documented plantar fasciitis, predominantly women (85%), mean age 52.2 ± 9.9 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and treat the metabolic and nutritional complications of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is effective for durable weight loss and may cure obesity-related comorbidities like diabetes, but it carries risks such as dumping syndrome, GERD, and nutrient deficiencies, necessitating rigorous pre- and postoperative nutritional management.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific population not further detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the pathophysiology of early diabetic kidney disease in youth-onset type 2 diabetes and explore potential treatments, including bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bariatric surgery as a promising novel therapy but does not provide specific results regarding its effects.
population_specificity: Youth with type 2 diabetes, particularly those with diabetic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on liver damage associated with older and newer types of bariatric surgeries.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery often improves non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and steatohepatitis but has also been linked to acute liver failure and chronic liver disease progressing to cirrhosis. Liver damage has been reported after almost all types of bariatric surgeries, with protein-calorie malnutrition, bacterial overgrowth, and genetic factors playing key roles.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether obesity or depression contributes more to peripheral low-grade inflammation and how bariatric surgery affects depressive symptoms and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that changes in BMI, including after bariatric surgery, were associated with reduced depressive scores, but high CRP levels remained linked to depression even after BMI adjustment, suggesting inflammation may independently contribute to depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and symptoms of depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) concepts increased the proportion of bariatric surgery patients discharged on postoperative day 1 and assessed secondary outcomes like length of stay, opioid use, and readmissions.
results_summary: ERAS implementation did not significantly increase day-1 discharges but reduced perioperative opioid use, postoperative nausea, and early emergency visits. Length of stay decreased for gastric bypass procedures, though readmission rates remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing primary bariatric surgery at a large metropolitan university tertiary hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy on body composition, physical activity, dietary intake, and other health-related outcomes in patients with severe obesity.
results_summary: The study will assess changes in body weight, body fat, lean muscle mass, physical function, dietary intake, and quality of life over a 12-month period following bariatric surgery, but specific results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: 100 patients with severe obesity undergoing primary Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy in London, UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness and implementation of bariatric surgery for treating obesity and metabolic syndrome, focusing on identifying suitable patient populations.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be highly effective for weight loss and improving metabolic conditions like cardiovascular risk, dyslipidaemia, and glucose homeostasis. The study highlights the need for proper patient selection and follow-up to maintain outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and metabolic syndrome (e.g., hypertension, dyslipidaemia, glucose intolerance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical benefits of bariatric surgery for severe obesity and moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is likely the most adequate treatment for severe obesity and moderate to severe OSA, as it effectively reduces weight and improves OSA, thereby decreasing cardiovascular risks. Lifestyle modifications and drug therapy were noted as preferred for general obesity, but bariatric surgery was highlighted for severe cases.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity and moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of weight loss achieved through bariatric surgery in improving rheumatic diseases by reducing inflammatory pathways.
results_summary: The study found that weight loss from bariatric surgery reduced serum inflammatory markers, leading to improvement in some rheumatic diseases and decreased use of medications like steroids and immunosuppressors. The review included diverse study types but lacked large-scale randomized trials.
population_specificity: Obese patients suffering from rheumatic diseases (Rheumatoid Arthritis, Psoriasis, Psoriatic Arthritis, Fibromyalgia, Osteoarthritis, Systemic Lupus Erythematous).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of routine early postoperative upper gastrointestinal study (UGI) versus CT scan for detecting leaks after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that UGI had low sensitivity (54%) and high heterogeneity, while CT scan showed higher efficacy in detecting postoperative leaks, particularly in symptomatic patients. The authors concluded that CT scan should be the first-line procedure for detecting leaks after sleeve gastrectomy or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery (7,516 patients across 18 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare glycemic control and other health outcomes in severely obese adolescents with type 2 diabetes undergoing bariatric surgery versus medical therapy.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with better glycemic control (reduced hemoglobin A1c), significant weight loss (29% BMI reduction), and improvement in comorbidities compared to medical therapy, which showed worsening glycemic control and slight BMI increase. However, 23% of surgical participants required a subsequent operation within 2 years.
population_specificity: Severely obese adolescents (aged 10-19 years) with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (surgical intervention details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of joint pain and osteoarthritis in morbidly obese patients referred for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence of joint pain (90.1%) and osteoarthritis (63.1% in knees, 40.8% in hips) among morbidly obese patients referred for bariatric surgery. Age, pain scores (VAS), and functional impairment (WOMAC) were higher in patients with osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (mean BMI 46, 85.1% women, mean age 40 years) referred for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG), LSG with duodenojejunal bypass (LSG-DJB), and laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (LAGB) on metabolic disorders and intestinal microbiota in Japanese patients with obesity.
results_summary: LSG and LSG-DJB significantly improved metabolic disorders in obese patients, with distinct changes in intestinal microbiota—Bacteroidetes and Lactobacillales increased in LSG, while Enterobacteriales increased in LSG-DJB. The differing microbiota impacts may explain the varying efficacy of these procedures in resolving metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: 44 Japanese patients with obesity (22 LSG, 18 LSG-DJB, 4 LAGB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight cases where bariatric patients had anatomical variations from the standard Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) to raise awareness among surgeons.
results_summary: The study identified six cases with aberrant RYGB anatomy, demonstrating that some "Roux-en-Y gastric bypasses" had no resemblance to the standard procedure. Adjunctive diagnostic methods like upper gastrointestinal studies and endoscopies were crucial for accurate diagnosis.
population_specificity: Patients who believed they received RYGBs but had anatomical deviations (retrospective case series over 12 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the development of novel anti-obesity therapies, including bariatric surgery, for patients failing lifestyle therapies.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on bariatric surgery, focusing instead on the pipeline of new anti-obesity drugs and their potential.
population_specificity: Persons with obesity failing lifestyle therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to introduce the BOSSSS program, a holistic, skill-based intervention designed to promote long-term weight loss, prevent weight regain, and improve well-being in bariatric surgery patients with severe obesity and problematic eating behaviors.
results_summary: Preliminary survey data indicated a lack of long-term emotional and behavioral support for bariatric surgery patients. The BOSSSS program, rooted in self-determination theory and integrating mobile health technology, was well received by patients and could be implemented by healthcare professionals with minimal support.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity and a history of bariatric surgery, particularly those with binge eating disorder, food addiction, or dysregulated overeating.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze early changes in vitamin B12 status biomarkers following bariatric surgery, comparing Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB) and Sleeve Gastrectomy (SG).
results_summary: The study found that B12 status decreased post-surgery, with significant reductions in holotranscobalamin (holoTC) and increases in methylmalonic acid (MMA) as early as 2 months postoperatively, worsening by 6 months. B12 absorption capacity also declined, suggesting the need for immediate postoperative B12 supplementation.
population_specificity: Adult patients (n=27) referred for RYGB (n=19) or SG (n=8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether hs-CRP levels could predict adiposity and clinical response to bariatric surgery differently in obese males and females.
results_summary: Obese females had higher hs-CRP levels, which were associated with visceral fat area (VFA) and predicted greater VFA reduction post-surgery. Post-surgery hs-CRP decreases correlated with improved weight, BMI, and fat mass reductions, particularly in females with high baseline hs-CRP.
population_specificity: 110 morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (gender-specific analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of weight loss induced by bariatric surgery on inflammatory markers (TNF-α, adiponectin, leptin) in severely obese patients.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly reduced inflammatory markers (inflammome state) in severely obese patients after 6 months, while no significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 55 severely obese patients (50 women, age 18-63, BMI 35.7-63 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers sought to understand the circumstances leading to emergency department visits after elective, primary bariatric surgery to identify intervention opportunities.
results_summary: The study found that most patients visited the ED for non-life-threatening symptoms like abdominal pain and nausea/vomiting, believing their concerns required immediate attention. Despite high compliance with perioperative measures, many did not seek lower-acuity alternatives like urgent care.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent elective, primary bariatric surgery across 40 hospitals in Michigan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the implications of standardized management protocols (ERAS, fast-track protocols) on outcomes in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Standardized perioperative techniques reduced operative time by 19.5 minutes and shortened hospital stays by 1.5 days, with lower post-operative morbidity rates favoring enhanced recovery protocols.
population_specificity: 6,172 patients undergoing bariatric surgery (meta-analysis of 13 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether metabolic interventions like bariatric surgery could improve cognitive function in individuals with mood disorders and obesity.
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery, along with other weight-loss interventions, may beneficially affect cognitive function, potentially mitigating deficits associated with mood disorders and obesity.
population_specificity: Adults with mood disorders (major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder) and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between bone marrow fat (BMF) and skeletal health, particularly focusing on the impact of bariatric surgery on BMF and bone loss.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery induces bone loss and fractures, with varying effects on marrow fat depending on diabetic status. The relationship between marrow fat and bone mineral density (BMD) was negatively associated, but data on fractures remain limited.
population_specificity: Healthy and osteoporotic populations, including individuals with metabolic diseases like diabetes mellitus, obesity, and anorexia nervosa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of late gastric perforation after adjustable intragastric balloon placement and review literature on this complication.
results_summary: The study found a rare case of gastric perforation 13 months after intragastric balloon placement, successfully repaired laparoscopically. It highlights the importance of timely balloon removal and regular follow-up to prevent complications.
population_specificity: 42-year-old female patient with obesity who underwent intragastric adjustable balloon placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically review clinical and preclinical studies on deep brain stimulation as a potential treatment for obesity, focusing on its effects on the gut-brain axis.
results_summary: Preclinical studies showed that deep brain stimulation of the hypothalamus or nucleus accumbens induces weight loss, with potential mechanisms including reduced food intake or increased energy expenditure. Clinical data remain limited and mixed, with ongoing trials needed to draw clear conclusions.
population_specificity: Animal models of obesity and six human patients (clinical data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify whether post-surgery emotional food cravings predicted inadequate weight loss outcomes at 6 months following laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: Participants lost an average of 64% excess weight loss (EWL) 6-8 months post-LSG. Emotional food cravings were found to significantly predict failure to achieve EWL, suggesting they may be a maladaptive coping mechanism requiring early psychological intervention.
population_specificity: 106 participants (80.7% female) who underwent LSG at four sites.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare bariatric surgery outcomes, including weight loss and comorbidity remission, between Medicaid beneficiaries and commercially insured patients in the U.S.
results_summary: Weight loss and comorbidity remission at 1-2 years post-surgery were similar between Medicaid and commercially insured patients, but Medicaid recipients had worse short-term outcomes, including longer hospital stays and higher mortality. The study highlights gaps in understanding baseline health differences and their impact on postoperative results.
population_specificity: U.S. adult Medicaid recipients and commercially insured patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to equip general practitioners with guidance on managing the comprehensive psychological, nutritional, and exercise needs of obese patients before and after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study highlights the increasing prevalence of bariatric surgery in Australia and emphasizes the importance of pre-operative and postoperative management by GPs, particularly in psychological, nutritional, and exercise interventions. It provides expert-backed resources for GPs to support patients when allied health providers are unavailable.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing or considering bariatric surgery in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neurological complications associated with bariatric surgery and emphasize the importance of early detection and management to prevent significant morbidity and mortality.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can lead to a broad spectrum of neurological disorders, with central nervous system complications being less common but more severe. Early diagnosis and treatment can improve or reverse these complications, highlighting the need for physician awareness.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery, particularly those with morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of an online lecture on nutrition knowledge, weight loss expectations, and anxiety among bariatric surgery candidates and to present a new tool for assessing this knowledge.
results_summary: The study found that education via an online lecture prior to surgery improved bariatric surgery nutrition knowledge but did not reduce anxiety. Data was available for 128 patients, with no significant impact on anxiety levels.
population_specificity: 200 bariatric surgery candidates (mean age 40.3 ± 11.4 years, mean BMI 41.3 ± 4.9 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 15-minute online lecture, viewed 1-2 weeks prior to surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the EndoBarrier®, a duodenal-jejunal sleeve bypass, as an alternative treatment for diabetes mellitus in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in weight, BMI, and HbA1c levels, along with improvements in metabolic parameters. Adverse events were mostly mild, suggesting the treatment is safe and effective.
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes (BMI 30-50 kg/m²) in the UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare weight loss outcomes between patients required versus not required to complete an insurance-mandated preoperative diet before bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Patients without the insurance-mandated diet requirement had superior weight loss outcomes at 6, 12, and 24 months postoperation, with no difference in complication rates or length of stay. The mandated diet delayed treatment and was associated with inferior weight loss.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy at a U.S. university hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgeon expertise improves outcomes in obese patients requiring acute nonbariatric surgical interventions.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgeon expertise was associated with shorter hospital stays and increased use of laparoscopy, suggesting potential benefits in nonbariatric emergencies. However, further research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Obese patients requiring acute surgical intervention at a community teaching hospital in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate gut-derived signals and their role in modulating outcomes after bariatric surgery, focusing on mechanisms beyond caloric restriction.
results_summary: The study found that bile acid metabolic pathways, luminal contents, energy balance, gut mucosal integrity, and gut microbiota are significantly modulated after bariatric surgery, potentially explaining variable outcomes. The workshop fostered interdisciplinary collaboration and advanced new research hypotheses for obesity interventions.
population_specificity: Clinicians and researchers across the scientific spectrum (specific patient population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between bariatric surgery and changes in antidiabetes treatment over 6 years compared to a matched obese control group.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with significantly higher antidiabetes treatment discontinuation rates (49.9% vs. 9.0%) and lower initiation rates (1.4% vs. 12.0%) compared to controls. Gastric bypass showed the strongest effect on discontinuation and prevention of new antidiabetes treatment.
population_specificity: 15,650 obese patients (84.6% female, mean age 38.9) in France undergoing bariatric surgery in 2009, matched with non-surgical obese controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and risks of bariatric surgery in obese women by comparing obstetric outcomes between those who underwent surgery and a control group matched for presurgery BMI.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with reduced rates of gestational diabetes, large-for-gestational-age infants, gestational hypertension, hypertensive disorders, postpartum hemorrhage, and cesarean delivery, but increased risks of small-for-gestational-age infants, intrauterine growth restriction, and preterm deliveries. No differences were found in preeclampsia, neonatal ICU admissions, stillbirths, malformations, or neonatal death.
population_specificity: Obese women who underwent bariatric surgery and subsequently became pregnant, compared to a control group matched for presurgery BMI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current status and foreseen innovations in gastrointestinal stenting for post-bariatric surgery leaks.
results_summary: The study found that endoscopic therapy with self-expandable stents and double-pigtail stents is effective for managing post-bariatric surgery leaks, though self-expandable stents have migration and tolerability issues. Most studies pooled leaks from different etiologies, limiting specificity.
population_specificity: Patients with post-bariatric surgery leaks.

study_goal: The researchers did not directly study bariatric surgery but mentioned post-bariatric surgery hypoglycemia as a potential use case for stable liquid glucagon.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on bariatric surgery, only noting post-bariatric surgery hypoglycemia as an area where stable liquid glucagon could be beneficial.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on type 1 diabetes and general hypoglycemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate strategies mimicking bariatric surgery effects by delivering food-related stimuli to the distal gastrointestinal tract to enhance gut hormone release.
results_summary: The study reviewed various methods, including nutrient, bile acid, fatty acid, and bitter compound delivery, showing potential to enhance gut hormone release like GLP-1 and PYY. Outcomes were supported by intestinal perfusion studies.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied agents tested in capsules, microcapsules, or pellets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, effectiveness, and tolerance of the Orbera intragastric balloon (OIB) in real-world clinical settings, including factors associated with intolerance and response.
results_summary: The study found the OIB to be safe and effective for weight loss, with significant improvements in obesity-related comorbidities. Early removal rates were 16.7%, primarily influenced by the use of selective serotonin or serotonin-norepinephrine re-uptake inhibitors.
population_specificity: 321 patients (mean age 48.1 ± 11.9 years, 80% female, baseline BMI 37.6 ± 6.9) from 8 centers (3 academic, 5 private).
interactions: Selective serotonin or serotonin-norepinephrine re-uptake inhibitors were associated with increased odds of early balloon removal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate metabolic changes after laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy in obese patients with T2DM and compare the molecular mechanisms of these procedures.
results_summary: The study identified 49 significant metabolites linked to various pathways and proposed a "gear mechanism" for molecular changes. Both procedures showed similar clinical outcomes but differed in underlying molecular mechanisms.
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) who underwent bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Six months (with follow-ups at one and six months post-surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms behind GLP-1 receptor signaling and trafficking in pancreatic beta cells to develop more effective GLP-1 analogues for improving glycaemic control post-bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that low-affinity GLP-1 agonists, which cause less receptor internalization, enhance insulin secretion and improve glycaemia more effectively than high-affinity compounds. These findings suggest potential for developing new GLP-1 analogues with improved clinical efficacy.
population_specificity: Pancreatic beta cells (in vitro or animal models, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of bariatric surgery on stone formation, fertility in men, and erectile function.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery increases oxalate absorption, leading to hyperoxaluria and higher urinary calcium oxalate supersaturation, which may contribute to stone formation. Data on fertility and erectile function post-surgery were conflicting, indicating a need for further research.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients, with a focus on men regarding fertility and erectile function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of different types of bariatric surgery on type 2 diabetes (T2D) remission and glycemic control, as well as the mechanisms behind these effects.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery, particularly Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB) and Bilio-Pancreatic Diversion (BPD), effectively improves insulin sensitivity and glycemic control, with remission or significant improvement of T2D lasting at least 5 years. The study discusses the foregut and hindgut hypotheses to explain early T2D remission post-surgery, with GLP-1 being a key candidate hormone, though its direct role in reducing insulin resistance remains controversial.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the variability in improvements of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) and other sleep parameters in response to weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract notes that weight loss, including through bariatric surgery, can improve OSAS, but there is high variability in individual responses. Maintenance of weight loss remains challenging, influencing the long-term treatment of sleep disorders.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, OSAS, and/or sleep disruptions (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and risks of bariatric (metabolic) surgery, focusing on optimizing clinical pathways to maximize metabolic benefits while reducing complications.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery improves glycaemia, blood pressure, and dyslipidaemia but is associated with major surgical and medical complications, including reflux disease, malnutrition, and micronutrient deficiencies. Strategies to mitigate risks include preoperative assessment and lifelong nutritional supplementation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of bariatric surgery patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of weight-loss interventions, including bariatric surgery, on survival and adverse events in obese women with endometrial cancer.
results_summary: The study found insufficient high-quality evidence to assess the effect of bariatric surgery on survival or weight loss in endometrial cancer patients, with no specific data reported for bariatric surgery outcomes.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese women with endometrial cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of age on perioperative and one-year postoperative outcomes of Laparoscopic Sleeve Gastrectomy (LSG) and Laparoscopic Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (LRYGB).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is safe and feasible for patients over 50, with no differences in adverse events, reoperation, or readmission rates between age groups. However, weight loss outcomes (excess weight loss and excess BMI loss) were slightly worse in patients over 50.
population_specificity: Patients qualified for primary LSG or LRYGB, divided into groups ≥50 and <50 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) in obese patients and review existing literature on the topic.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery led to sustained weight loss and resolution of IIH symptoms in one patient, while conservative weight management failed to alleviate symptoms in another. A literature review showed 84% of patients experienced weight loss and symptom improvement post-surgery.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients diagnosed with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a new clinical prioritization system (Obesity Surgery Score, OSS) for bariatric surgery waiting lists based on obesity severity and waiting time.
results_summary: The study found that patients with higher OSS grades (C) had greater BMI, more severe comorbidities, and longer waiting times. Implementing the OSS could prioritize higher-risk patients, improving prognosis and resource optimization.
population_specificity: Patients on bariatric surgery waiting lists in public hospitals, categorized by obesity severity (grades A, B, or C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide updates on obesity pharmacotherapy, including bariatric surgery as an adjunctive therapy, but did not focus on evaluating its safety or efficacy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on bariatric surgery's effects, as it primarily reviews pharmacological management and FDA-approved weight loss medications.
population_specificity: Not specified for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms of action of bariatric surgery and endoscopic methods in treating type 2 diabetes and obesity, focusing on their role in glucose homeostasis.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is highly effective in modifying diabetes progression or achieving remission, with multiple mechanisms involved, including changes in gastrointestinal hormones, bile acids, and gut microbiota. Endoscopic methods based on bariatric principles also showed promising results.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and accompanying pathologies like obesity, arterial hypertension, and dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of incretin hormones (GIP and GLP-1) in the pathophysiology of obesity and type 2 diabetes, and how bariatric surgery (e.g., Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) may influence GLP-1 secretion and improve metabolic outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery increases GLP-1 secretion, which contributes to weight loss and improved glycemic control in obese individuals with type 2 diabetes. GLP-1's effects on appetite reduction and glucose metabolism were highlighted as key mechanisms.
population_specificity: Obese subjects and individuals with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of bariatric surgery in obese patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and how weight loss might alter the course of IBD.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric surgery's safety and efficacy in obese IBD patients are emerging areas of interest, but specific findings are not detailed. It highlights the need for future studies to determine the impact of weight loss on IBD progression.
population_specificity: Obese patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the complications and outcomes of different brachioplasty techniques following bariatric surgery through a literature review.
results_summary: The study found that brachioplasty is generally safe with positive outcomes, but minor complications like hypertrophic scarring and nerve injuries occurred in 28.9% of patients. No major complications were reported.
population_specificity: 1065 patients who underwent brachioplasty after bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of bariatric surgery on intestinal fatty acid uptake and blood flow in morbidly obese subjects, including those with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Morbidly obese subjects had higher duodenal and jejunal fatty acid uptake compared to lean controls, which further increased post-surgery. Bariatric surgery led to significant weight loss and diabetes remission in most subjects but reduced jejunal blood flow while preserving duodenal blood flow.
population_specificity: 27 morbidly obese subjects (10 with type 2 diabetes) and 15 healthy age-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on weight loss, particularly durable and significant weight loss after bariatric surgery, as a potential intervention for pancreatic cancer prevention.
results_summary: The study found that obesity is associated with increased pancreatic cancer incidence and potentially worse outcomes, while weight loss, especially after bariatric surgery, may reduce cancer risks. Chronic inflammation, insulin resistance, and altered gut microbiota are implicated in obesity's carcinogenic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent advances in understanding obesity-related kidney disease and assess the role of bariatric surgery as a treatment option.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery improves kidney function and reduces albuminuria in both children and adults with obesity-related kidney disease. It also highlighted that obesity itself contributes to chronic kidney disease independently of metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Children and adults with obesity-related kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of bariatric surgery versus specialized medical treatment on obesity-related comorbidities and adverse outcomes in patients with severe obesity.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with greater remission rates for hypertension and diabetes but also higher risks of new-onset depression, opioid use, additional gastrointestinal procedures, and low ferritin levels compared to medical treatment.
population_specificity: Adults with severe obesity (BMI ≥40 or ≥35 with at least 1 comorbidity) in Norway.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of sleeve gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in terms of weight loss, comorbidity changes, quality of life, and adverse events.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in excess BMI loss between the two procedures at 5 years. However, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass showed better remission of gastric reflux, while sleeve gastrectomy had fewer reoperations or interventions.
population_specificity: 217 morbidly obese patients (mean age 45.5 years, 72% women, mean BMI 43.9) from 4 Swiss bariatric centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of vertical sleeve gastrectomy in treating obesity and type 2 diabetes, focusing on weight loss and glycemic control outcomes.
results_summary: Short-term weight loss was greater with vertical sleeve gastrectomy compared to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, and diabetes remission occurred in up to 60% of patients after one year. However, long-term durability of these benefits was questioned, as remission rates between surgical and clinical groups showed no significant difference after three years.
population_specificity: Obese patients with or without type 2 diabetes.
study_duration: Follow-up periods included one year and three years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and adverse effects of Billroth II anastomosis versus Roux-en-Y gastrojejunal anastomosis in bariatric surgery, focusing on bile reflux and mucosal damage.
results_summary: The study found that bile reflux and its complications are more frequent after Billroth II operations compared to Roux-en-Y gastrojejunal anastomosis, based on historical data from peptic disease and gastric cancer surgeries. These findings suggest caution in selecting anastomosis techniques for bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery, with historical data from peptic disease and gastric cancer surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare anthropometric variables, body composition, and physical fitness between women who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (via private or public healthcare) and those who did not.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the operated (private/public) and non-operated groups in the studied variables. However, sedentary operated women showed higher anthropometric and fat percentage indices compared to sedentary non-operated women. Physical activity positively influenced anthropometric and body composition outcomes in operated individuals.
population_specificity: 108 women subdivided into private healthcare-operated (n=36), public healthcare-operated (n=36), and non-operated (n=36) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the roles of bile acids in glucose metabolism and explore how bariatric surgery improves glycemic response in morbidly obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery in morbidly obese patients leads to significant improvement in glycemic response, associated with changes in bile acid profile and signaling. It highlights the potential of bile acids as therapeutic targets for hyperglycemia and diabetes.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to reflect on obesity concepts in children and adolescents, including its history, epidemiology, complications, and management principles.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Bariatric Surgery's effects, focusing instead on broader obesity-related topics.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and long-term weight maintenance potential of the closed-loop gastric electrical stimulation (CLGES) system in limiting weight regain after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that CLGES limited weight regain, with mean percent total body weight loss (%TBWL) changing by only 1.5% between 12 and 24 months. Safety outcomes were strong, with no serious adverse events in the second year, and improvements in quality of life and cardiovascular risk factors remained stable.
population_specificity: Adults who underwent laparoscopic implantation of a CLGES system (n=47 initially, n=35 at 24 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare 6-month and 1-year postoperative remission rates of type 2 diabetes (T2D) in obese patients after bariatric surgery, stratified by preoperative A1C levels and pharmacologic therapy (insulin-dependent vs. noninsulin-dependent).
results_summary: Lower preoperative A1C levels correlated with higher remission rates, but insulin-dependent diabetic (IDD) patients had lower remission rates than noninsulin-dependent (NIDD) patients regardless of A1C levels. IDD patients showed similar remission rates across A1C levels, while NIDD patients' remission rates were less affected by A1C levels.
population_specificity: 186 obese patients with type 2 diabetes who underwent sleeve gastrectomy or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.

study_goal: The researchers sought to examine the effect of diagnosed mental health disorders on 30-day readmission rates for patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Patients with diagnosed mental health disorders had 34% greater odds of 30-day readmission, and those with major depressive disorder/bipolar disorder had 46% greater odds compared to those without such diagnoses. The study suggests the need for preoperative risk assessment and additional discharge interventions for at-risk patients.
population_specificity: Patients aged >18 years who underwent bariatric surgery in Pennsylvania hospitals or freestanding surgical facilities from 2011 to 2014.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop recommendations for managing obesity among workers and explore the impact of obesity on health costs to justify surgical interventions and insurance coverage.
results_summary: The study found that both lifestyle modification and bariatric surgery are effective for weight loss in appropriate patients, though more research is needed in certain areas.
population_specificity: Workers with obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of laparoscopic single anastomosis (mini-)gastric bypass (LSAGB) in treating morbid obesity and metabolic disorders, comparing it with other bariatric procedures.
results_summary: The study found that LSAGB resulted in sustained weight loss and high resolution of comorbidities, demonstrating its effectiveness for treating morbid obesity and metabolic disorders. However, long-term outcome data remain lacking.
population_specificity: 1731 morbidly obese patients with a mean BMI of 40.4 kg/m² and average age of 33.8 years.
study_duration: Follow-up from October 2001 to December 2015 (14 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the challenges and risks associated with pregnancy following bariatric surgery and provide recommendations for optimal care.
results_summary: The study found that pregnancy post-bariatric surgery presents risks of malnutrition and micronutrient deficiencies, necessitating delayed pregnancy (≥12 months post-surgery) and specialized multidisciplinary care with close monitoring.
population_specificity: Women who become pregnant after undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of bariatric surgery for sustained weight loss and resolution of type 2 diabetes in patients with severe obesity.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to yield substantial and sustained weight loss with resolution of type 2 diabetes, though it carries a small risk of serious complications and is generally recommended for severe obesity cases. The benefit-to-risk balance should guide treatment decisions.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature to determine if patients who underwent bariatric surgery have a greater risk of dental caries.
results_summary: The study found that patients who underwent bariatric surgery may have a higher risk of dental caries, and oral complications could be minimized by including dental professionals in multidisciplinary treatment.
population_specificity: Humans who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe evidence-based obesity treatment strategies, including bariatric surgery, for women presenting at obstetric and gynecologic clinics.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery is one of the evidence-based strategies for obesity treatment, suggesting its potential benefit in this clinical setting. However, specific outcomes or results related to bariatric surgery are not detailed.
population_specificity: Women presenting at obstetric and gynecologic clinics, particularly those with or at risk for obesity and associated comorbid conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a ventilator-piloted pulmonary recruitment maneuver (PRM) reduces postoperative pain and nausea after laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The PRM significantly reduced postoperative pain intensity and opioid requirements within the first 24 hours compared to routine exsufflation, but it did not affect nausea or vomiting.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective laparoscopic bariatric surgery at a secondary-level public hospital in Sweden.
study_duration: Postoperative effects were measured up to 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to classify and analyze complications associated with bariatric surgery procedures (AGB, SG, GBP) to guide physicians in managing these complications.
results_summary: The study identified early and late complications for each bariatric surgery type, such as prosthetic slippage for AGB, staple line leaks for SG, and fistulas for GBP, and developed decision algorithms for managing these complications.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing adjustable gastric band (AGB), sleeve gastrectomy (SG), or gastric bypass (GBP) procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare progression rates to bariatric surgery and weight loss outcomes between live and online seminar attendees.
results_summary: Live seminar attendees had significantly higher progression rates to office visits (78.1% vs. 66.5%) and surgery (40.1% vs. 29.7%) compared to online attendees. Demographic factors like sex and BMI were similar, but online attendees were younger.
population_specificity: Prospective bariatric surgery patients attending live or online seminars at a University Hospital Network in Allentown, PA, USA.
study_duration: Data collected from November 2011 to September 2015, with 1-year postoperation follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the progress and effectiveness of bariatric and metabolic endoscopic methods for weight loss and managing obesity-related comorbidities.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric and metabolic endoscopy has advanced rapidly, with the intragastric balloon (IGB) being the most mature and widely used method. However, new endoscopic devices lack sufficient clinical data and experience for widespread adoption.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, particularly those with related comorbidities like diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and coronary heart disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify barriers to the underutilization of bariatric surgery among adults with severe obesity using Andersen's Behavioral Model of Health Services Use.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for weight loss and resolution of obesity-related co-morbidities, yet fewer than 1% of eligible adults undergo the procedure annually due to contextual and individual factors.
population_specificity: Adults with severe obesity in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different bariatric surgery procedures (gastric band, gastric sleeve, and gastric bypass) for weight loss in obese adolescents and young adults.
results_summary: The study conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to estimate absolute changes in BMI following bariatric surgery, but specific results on weight loss outcomes are not detailed in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Obese adolescent patients (age ≤19) and young adults (age ≤21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the main concerns and doubts expressed by bariatric surgery patients in blogs during the postoperative period.
results_summary: The study identified key areas of patient concern, including diet evolution, weight loss, plateau effect, weight regain, physical exercises, physiological changes, complications, and contraceptive use/pregnancy. The findings highlight the need for better patient education and preparation for the postoperative period.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery and posted about their experiences in blogs between October 2013 and May 2017.
study_duration: Not applicable (study analyzed existing blog posts)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) reduces the incidence of symptomatic gallstone disease after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy and assess its cost-effectiveness.
results_summary: The study is a randomized, placebo-controlled trial evaluating UDCA's effectiveness in preventing gallstone disease post-bariatric surgery, with primary and secondary endpoints including symptomatic gallstone disease, gallstone development, cholecystectomies, side effects, and quality of life. Results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Consecutive patients scheduled for Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy in three Dutch bariatric centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of very low calorie diets (VLCD) on liver size and weight loss during the bariatric surgery preoperative period, as well as evaluate surgery-related complications.
results_summary: VLCD treatment led to significant weight loss (2.8 to 14.8 kg) and liver size reduction (5% to 20% of initial volume), but did not significantly reduce perioperative complications, except for one study reporting a protective effect 30 days post-surgery.
population_specificity: Adult patients (aged >18 years) undergoing bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (VLCD treatment varied from 10 days to 12 weeks).

study_goal: To review the current evidence on the safety and efficacy of bariatric surgery in the elderly population.
results_summary: Historically, bariatric surgery in the elderly was associated with poorer outcomes, but recent studies show improved morbidity and mortality comparable to younger populations, attributed to better patient selection and surgical techniques.
population_specificity: Elderly obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of sustained deep neuromuscular blockade during laparoscopic bariatric surgery and other procedures.
results_summary: The study found that deep neuromuscular blockade improves surgical conditions in laparoscopic bariatric surgery and may reduce perioperative complications and improve patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic surgical procedures, including bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term course of loss-of-control (LOC) eating in adolescent bariatric surgery patients and its associations with weight outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that LOC eating decreased significantly from presurgery to 6-months postsurgery but increased thereafter. Postoperative LOC eating was associated with poorer long-term weight outcomes, though presurgical LOC eating did not affect weight loss.
population_specificity: Adolescents undergoing bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Follow-up at 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months postsurgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of surgically treating hiatal weakness on GERD symptoms in patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: GERD-HRQL scores significantly improved post-operatively, with the most notable improvements in patients with pre-operative reflux. Higher pre-operative reflux scores, younger age, and lower excess weight loss were associated with greater GERD-HRQL improvement.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing LSG at a single tertiary referral institution in Sydney, Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric/metabolic surgery in treating type 2 diabetes and its associated metabolic and cardiovascular benefits, including among patients with lower BMI ranges.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric/metabolic surgery leads to remission of type 2 diabetes in most cases, reduces cardiovascular risk factors, actual cardiovascular events, microvascular complications, cancer, and death, and is superior to non-surgical interventions for improving glycaemic and metabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes, including those with a preoperative BMI of 30-35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) as a stand-alone procedure in super-obese (SO) and super-super obese (SSO) patients.
results_summary: The study found that LSG was feasible and safe for resolving comorbidities in morbidly obese (MO), SO, and SSO patients, though %EWL was lower in the SSO group. Follow-up data showed sustained weight loss and comorbidity resolution over 41.2 months on average.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese (MO), super-obese (SO), and super-super obese (SSO) patients.

study_goal: To review the frequency, importance, and risk factors for early worsening of diabetic retinopathy (EWDR) after rapid improvement of blood glucose in patients with diabetes, including post-bariatric surgery.
results_summary: EWDR occurs in 10-20% of patients within 3-6 months after abrupt glucose control improvement, with higher rates in those with advanced baseline diabetic retinopathy. While often transient, it can cause irreversible retinal damage in severe cases.
population_specificity: Patients with uncontrolled type 1 or 2 diabetes, including those who underwent bariatric surgery or pancreas transplantation.
study_duration: Monitoring occurred quarterly for high-risk patients and every 6 months for others in the year following intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the frequency of postprandial hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia (pHH) with or without symptoms after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
results_summary: The study found that 11.5% of patients experienced pHH after a carbohydrate-rich meal, with 5.3% being asymptomatic; no hypoglycemia occurred after a protein-rich meal. One patient required emergency treatment due to sudden loss of consciousness.
population_specificity: Consecutive, unselected patients approximately one year after uncomplicated RYGB.
